awd_titl_txt: An Artificial Intelligence Method for Auto-Compressed Sensing and Blind Deconvolution in Magnetic Resonance Imaging Data of Shoulder Muscle Metabolism
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2021 Mathematical and Physical Sciences Ascending Postdoctoral Research Fellowships, MPS-Ascend Program. Talon Johnson is awarded this fellowship to conduct a program of research and education in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, at University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center under the mentorship of the sponsoring scientists Jimin Ren and Anke Henning. This is a research project aimed at development of computational image reconstruction methods for Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).  Johnson plans to design compressed sensing methods that are capable of reconstructing image data from MRI measurements that have been affected by the subject's motion, such as respiratory-related motion in MRI imaging of shoulder muscle metabolism.  Along with this research, Johnson will be involved in activities to broaden participation of underrepresented minorities in mathematical sciences through the recruitment of students from the University of Texas at Arlington and a collaboration with the Atlanta University Center Data Science Initiative.

This research is aimed at improving image precision and quality by completing three research objectives: 1) Develop and refine the methodology for reconstruction of compressed sensing data for blurred MRI imaging using l1-l2 minimization scheme, based on l1-magic for compressed sensing and l2 minimization for deconvolution of a fixed kernel function, 2) develop an AI method for auto-recognition of any unknown kernel functions from blurred compressed MRI data sets to achieve simultaneous compressed sensing - blind deblurring of any simulated MRI data, 3) refine the AI method for auto-compressed sensing and blind deblurring of experimental data in MRI imaging of shoulder muscle metabolism and improve imaging precision.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through this project, I aimed to improve Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy Imaging (MRSI) techniques to better understand fat infiltration in muscles and its link to metabolic diseases such as osteoporosis. By combining advanced imaging methods with mathematical modeling, I achieved significant advancements in both medical research and education.

One of the key scientific contributions of this project was the development of new data acquisition methods to enhance the efficiency and accuracy of MRI/MRSI in studying fat infiltration and bone density. MRI provides detailed structural images of muscles and bones, while MRSI measures the chemical composition within tissues, offering deeper insights into metabolic changes linked to aging and disease progression. Using high-resolution 7 Tesla (7T) MRI, I acquired muscle and bone anatomical data and spectroscopy data, but this process can be time-consuming. A major innovation of this project was the development of a compressed sensing method, which enables faster imaging while maintaining high-quality results. Compressed sensing is a mathematical technique that reconstructs images from fewer measurements, reducing scan times without compromising accuracy. However, there is still a need for testing this method on actual MRI machines and comparing the results with conventional imaging techniques, but this can have significant impacts on MRI technologies.

My research provided new insights into sex-specific patterns of musculoskeletal health. The findings revealed that fat infiltration increases with age in women and correlates with body mass index (BMI) in men. These discoveries contribute to a deeper understanding of how musculoskeletal conditions progress across different demographics. Additionally, I introduced the concept of the "bone g-factor," a novel metric to assess bone health non-invasively. The bone g-factor quantifies the relationship between bone thinning and marrow expansion, offering potential as an early biomarker for osteoporosis and related conditions.

Machine learning techniques played a crucial role in analyzing complex imaging data more effectively. Specifically, I applied fuzzy clustering to classify muscle fat infiltration severity, providing a more nuanced understanding of disease progression. Fuzzy clustering is particularly useful in medical imaging because it accommodates gradual transitions between healthy and diseased tissues, improving diagnostic precision. Furthermore, I employed dimensionality reduction techniques to highlight the most important features within the data, enhancing the efficiency and accuracy of classification models. These approaches have the potential to refine diagnostic tools and contribute to personalized treatment strategies.

Beyond scientific advancements, I placed a strong emphasis on education and community engagement, with a particular focus on increasing diversity in STEM fields. Collaborating with the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) and the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center (UTSW), I facilitated interdisciplinary opportunities that connected students and researchers across mathematics, biomedical engineering, and radiology. These collaborations provided students with hands-on experience working on real-world healthcare challenges while applying mathematical and computational methods to medical imaging.

A highlight of the project was my involvement with an educational outreach program designed to cultivate a vibrant mathematical community, the Mathposium. The Mathposium at UTA, which has seen substantial growth over the last three years with over 200 total participants in 2022 and 2023 combined, and over 150 participants in 2024 alone, is a student-led conference that empowers undergraduates to explore mathematical research and connect with professionals across diverse fields. The event features student research presentations, engaging activities, and the BIG Math Panel, where experts from business, industry, and government share insights on real-world applications of mathematics. Following Mathposium, the M&Ms (Mentor-Mentee Pairings) program extends the experience by matching undergraduate students with graduate mentors for ongoing discussions about academic and career growth, offering valuable guidance on school-life balance and post-graduation opportunities. These initiatives provide an inclusive and supportive environment, fostering connections, mentorship, and career development for students in mathematics and related STEM disciplines.

Through the inSTEM Mentors program, I provided mentorship and career guidance to students in the STEM field. This program aimed to bridge the gap between academia and industry by equipping students with the skills and confidence needed to succeed in STEM careers. The program created a supportive community that connected students with mentors and professional development opportunities, helping to foster an inclusive and diverse scientific workforce.

Ultimately, this project advanced MRI/MRSI techniques with the potential to improve the diagnosis and treatment of metabolic diseases, while also empowering a diverse group of students to pursue careers in STEM.
